_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Farmers Union Oil Company, Montevideo, MN, Wegdahl NH3 Plant, Chippewa County

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY - AMMONIA (anhydrous)

THE ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE & CONTINGENCY POLICIES FOR OUR FACILITY

This facility complies with the 1989 ANSI K61.1 "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".
In addition, it is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.

One of our company Goals states, "To provide for the Safety and Security of our employees, our customers, the general
public and to be good stewards of the environment for which we serve".  To fulfill these goals, we enroll in regulatory
management service that assists in maintaining and administering comprehensive safety and environmental programs,
procedures and training courses.  We perform a thorough annual audit program and monitor facility compliance with the
safety standards and overseen assistance with this specialty firm.  The program consists of internal audit utilizing checklist
survey forms that are reviewed regularly and updated as necessary to ensure all applicable federal, state, and local regulations
are covered.  These checklists are used to measure regulatory compliance including those governing the safe handling and
storage of anhydrous ammonia.  Procedures require a timely response and correction of all recommendations resulting
from these audit checklists.  

A "Site Safety Coordinator" is identified and used as an extension of the general manager and management service personnel
for a "hands on" manager of the day to day safe working activities, maintains the required regulatory recordkeeping, conducts
employee training, and acts as the location's contact during emergency incidents that are rehearsed biannually.

A DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The facility is a wholesale farm supply and distribution center and as such we store and distribute a wide variety of pesticides
and fertilizers in

cluding anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous Ammonia is received by truck, is handled and stored on-site and is a
regulated substance by the EPA requiring us to comply with this Risk Management Program.  We sell anhydrous ammonia
to growers in nurse tanks manufactured to the requirements to do such.  The customer applies the ammonia into the soil as
a needed source of nitrogen fertilizer for growing agricultural crops.  Ammonia is also used for blending into mixed grade
liquid fertilizers for crop production nutrients.

Anhydrous Ammonia is stored in 1 stationary storage tank with a capacity of 30,000 gallons.  131,000 pounds of Anhydrous
Ammonia is the maximum storage capacity of this stationary storage tank.

WORST CASE SCENARIO

Our worst case scenario is the loss of the total contents of the 30,000 gallon storage tank, when filled to the greatest amount
allowed (85% if capacity), released as a liquid over 10 minutes, resulting in total vaporization.  The maximum quantity released
would be 131,000 pounds.  According to DEGRADIS modeling, the distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 PPM)
would have off-site impact.  It should be noted that our company has never had a total release of an entire storage tank.

ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIO

The most common alternate release scenario(s) from an anhydrous ammonia storage facility would not reach an endpoint
off-site.  The alternate release scenario modeled for the purpose of this plan is a three-minute release from a stationary storage
tank representing a valve and hose failure requiring a manual shutdown.  The total amount of anhydrous ammonia released in
this scenario would be 300 pounds from a storage tank.  The distance to the endpoint would not have an impact.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The ammonia storage system is designed, installed and is maintained in accordance with ASTM standards and the ASME
codes.  This facility complies with the ANSI K61.1 st

andards (1989 edition), OSHA - 29 CFR 1910.111, EPA's Accidental
Release Prevention Rule as well as applicable federal, state, and local codes and regulations.

Our ammonia system is protected from major releases by internal excess flow valves, check valves, relief valves, manual
shutoffs and emergency shutoff valves.  The load-out risers used for the purpose of filling the nurse tanks are protected by
excess flow valves and fill line breakaways to immediately stop the flow of ammonia is a line or a hose would fail.  All of the
main storage tank valves and the riser load valves are locked when not in use.  Lighting for the facility has increased to
discourage the increase of meth theft.

Our anhydrous ammonia system is inspected on a regular basis with maintenance and preventive maintenance scheduled
and documented.  Liquid and vapor valves, hoses, excess flow valves, gauges, and relief valves are replaced when necessary
and/or according to the guidelines within the ANSI standards.

Training is provided to all employees at least annually, whenever there is a change in the process or whenever competency
with the regulations are questioned.  In accordance with the 1989 ANSI standards, training is also offered for all ammonia
customers to attend on a regular basis and offered to the local fire department personnel during their annual tour of our
facility and operations.  These training courses consist of classroom lecture, current and approved videos or compact disc,
testing both verbally and written, demonstration and observation for each person working with the process that are certified
while on-going job training is always improved upon.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There has been no accidents involving anhydrous ammonia that has caused deaths, recordable injuries, property or
environmental damage including evacuations on or off site.

The "EMERGENCY RESPONSE AND CONTINGENCY PLAN"

In the event of an emergency involving our ammonia system, it is our policy to notif

y the local community fire department and
request that they respond to the emergency with the facility's personnel assistance.  In preparation for this, we have coordinated
with all of the local response agencies by providing information and facilty tours annually to ensure that they are familiar with
and properly prepared for an incident at our facility.  This will help ensure that our community has the strategy for responding
to a mitigating the threat posed by an ammonia release.  This complies with the requirement of our facility to be included in
the community emergency response plan prepared under EPCRA and coordinated with our LEPC.

is true, accurate, and complete.
